Since ∥v−Pv∥ξ2≥0\|v - \Proj v\|_\xi^2 \geq 0∥v−Pv∥ξ2​≥0, we have:

∥v∥ξ2≥∥Pv∥ξ2.\|v\|_\xi^2 \geq \|\Proj v\|_\xi^2.∥v∥ξ2​≥∥Pv∥ξ2​.
(58)

Taking square roots of both sides (which preserves the inequality since both norms are non-negative):

∥Pv∥ξ≤∥v∥ξ.\|\Proj v\|_\xi \leq \|v\|_\xi.∥Pv∥ξ​≤∥v∥ξ​.
(59)

This holds for all vvv, so P\ProjP is non-expansive in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​.

Can Lπ\BellmanPiLπ​ be a Contraction in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​ ?¶

To show Lπ=rπ+γPπ\BellmanPi = r_\pi + \gamma \mathbf{P}_\piLπ​=rπ​+γPπ​ is a γ\gammaγ-contraction, we need to verify:

∥Lπv−Lπw∥ξ=∥γPπ(v−w)∥ξ=γ∥Pπ(v−w)∥ξ.\|\BellmanPi v - \BellmanPi w\|_\xi = \|\gamma \mathbf{P}_\pi (v - w)\|_\xi = \gamma \|\mathbf{P}_\pi (v - w)\|_\xi.∥Lπ​v−Lπ​w∥ξ​=∥γPπ​(v−w)∥ξ​=γ∥Pπ​(v−w)∥ξ​.
(60)

This will be at most γ∥v−w∥ξ\gamma \|v - w\|_\xiγ∥v−w∥ξ​ if Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ is non-expansive, meaning ∥Pπz∥ξ≤∥z∥ξ\|\mathbf{P}_\pi z\|_\xi \leq \|z\|_\xi∥Pπ​z∥ξ​≤∥z∥ξ​ for any vector zzz. So the key is to establish that Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ is non-expansive in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​.

Consider the squared norm of Pπz\mathbf{P}_\pi zPπ​z. By definition of the weighted norm:

∥Pπz∥ξ2=∑sξ(s)[(Pπz)(s)]2.\|\mathbf{P}_\pi z\|_\xi^2 = \sum_s \xi(s) [(\mathbf{P}_\pi z)(s)]^2.∥Pπ​z∥ξ2​=s∑​ξ(s)[(Pπ​z)(s)]2.
(61)

The sss-th component of Pπz\mathbf{P}_\pi zPπ​z is (Pπz)(s)=∑s′p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)(\mathbf{P}_\pi z)(s) = \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) z(s')(Pπ​z)(s)=∑s′​p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′). This is a weighted average of the values z(s′)z(s')z(s′) with weights p(s′∣s,π(s))p(s'|s,\pi(s))p(s′∣s,π(s)) that sum to one. Therefore:

∥Pπz∥ξ2=∑sξ(s)[∑s′p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)]2.\|\mathbf{P}_\pi z\|_\xi^2 = \sum_s \xi(s) \left[\sum_{s'} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) z(s')\right]^2.∥Pπ​z∥ξ2​=s∑​ξ(s)[s′∑​p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)]2.
(62)

Since the function x↦x2x \mapsto x^2x↦x2 is convex, Jensen’s inequality applied to the probability distribution p(⋅∣s,π(s))p(\cdot|s,\pi(s))p(⋅∣s,π(s)) gives:

[∑s′p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)]2≤∑s′p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)2.\left[\sum_{s'} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) z(s')\right]^2 \leq \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) z(s')^2.[s′∑​p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)]2≤s′∑​p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)2.
(63)

Substituting this into the norm expression:

∥Pπz∥ξ2≤∑sξ(s)∑s′p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)2=∑s′z(s′)2∑sξ(s)p(s′∣s,π(s)).\|\mathbf{P}_\pi z\|_\xi^2 \leq \sum_s \xi(s) \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) z(s')^2 = \sum_{s'} z(s')^2 \sum_s \xi(s) p(s'|s,\pi(s)).∥Pπ​z∥ξ2​≤s∑​ξ(s)s′∑​p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)2=s′∑​z(s′)2s∑​ξ(s)p(s′∣s,π(s)).
(64)

The stationarity condition ξ⊤Pπ=ξ⊤\xi^\top \mathbf{P}_\pi = \xi^\topξ⊤Pπ​=ξ⊤ means ∑sξ(s)p(s′∣s,π(s))=ξ(s′)\sum_s \xi(s) p(s'|s,\pi(s)) = \xi(s')∑s​ξ(s)p(s′∣s,π(s))=ξ(s′) for all s′s's′. Therefore:

∥Pπz∥ξ2≤∑s′z(s′)2ξ(s′)=∥z∥ξ2.\|\mathbf{P}_\pi z\|_\xi^2 \leq \sum_{s'} z(s')^2 \xi(s') = \|z\|_\xi^2.∥Pπ​z∥ξ2​≤s′∑​z(s′)2ξ(s′)=∥z∥ξ2​.
(65)

Taking square roots, ∥Pπz∥ξ≤∥z∥ξ\|\mathbf{P}_\pi z\|_\xi \leq \|z\|_\xi∥Pπ​z∥ξ​≤∥z∥ξ​, so Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ is non-expansive in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​. This makes Lπ=rπ+γPπ\BellmanPi = r_\pi + \gamma \mathbf{P}_\piLπ​=rπ​+γPπ​ a γ\gammaγ-contraction in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​. Composing with the non-expansive projection:

∥PLπv−PLπw∥ξ≤∥Lπv−Lπw∥ξ≤γ∥v−w∥ξ.\|\Proj \BellmanPi v - \Proj \BellmanPi w\|_\xi \leq \|\BellmanPi v - \BellmanPi w\|_\xi \leq \gamma \|v - w\|_\xi.∥PLπ​v−PLπ​w∥ξ​≤∥Lπ​v−Lπ​w∥ξ​≤γ∥v−w∥ξ​.
(66)

By Banach’s fixed-point theorem, PLπ\Proj \BellmanPiPLπ​ has a unique fixed point and iterates converge from any initialization.

Interpretation: The On-Policy Condition¶

The result shows that convergence depends on matching the weighting to the operator. We cannot choose an arbitrary weighted L2L^2L2 norm and expect PLπ\Proj \BellmanPiPLπ​ to be a contraction. Instead, the weighting ξ\xiξ must have a specific relationship with the transition matrix Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ in the operator Lπ\BellmanPiLπ​: namely, ξ\xiξ must be the stationary distribution of Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​. This is what makes the weighted geometry compatible with the operator’s structure. When this match holds, Jensen’s inequality gives us non-expansiveness of Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ in the ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​ norm, and the composition PLπ\Proj \BellmanPiPLπ​ inherits the contraction property.

In reinforcement learning, this has a practical interpretation. When we learn by following policy π\piπ and collecting transitions (s,a,r,s′)(s, a, r, s')(s,a,r,s′), the states we visit are distributed according to the stationary distribution of π\piπ. This is on-policy learning. The LSTD algorithm uses data sampled from this distribution, which means the empirical weighting naturally matches the operator structure. Our analysis shows that the iterative algorithm vk+1=PLπvkv_{k+1} = \Proj \BellmanPi v_kvk+1​=PLπ​vk​ converges to the same fixed point that LSTD computes in closed form.

This is fundamentally different from the monotone approximator theory. There, we required structural properties of P\ProjP itself (monotonicity, constant preservation) to guarantee that P\ProjP preserves the sup-norm contraction property of L\BellmanL. Here, we place no such restriction on P\ProjP—Galerkin projection is not monotone. Instead, convergence depends on matching the norm to the operator. When ξ\xiξ does not match the stationary distribution, as in off-policy learning where data comes from a different behavior policy, the Jensen inequality argument breaks down. The operator Pπ\mathbf{P}_\piPπ​ need not be non-expansive in ∥⋅∥ξ\|\cdot\|_\xi∥⋅∥ξ​, and PLπ\Proj \BellmanPiPLπ​ may fail to contract. This explains divergence phenomena such as Baird’s counterexample Baird (1995).

Why Not Bellman Optimality?¶

Can we extend this weighted L2L^2L2 analysis to the Bellman optimality operator Lv=max⁡a[ra+γPav]\Bellman v = \max_a [r_a + \gamma \mathbf{P}_a v]Lv=maxa​[ra​+γPa​v]? The answer is no, at least not with this approach. The obstacle appears at the Jensen inequality step. For policy evaluation, we had:

∥Pπz∥ξ2=∑sξ(s)[∑s′p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)]2.\|\mathbf{P}_\pi z\|_\xi^2 = \sum_s \xi(s) \left[\sum_{s'} p(s'|s,\pi(s)) z(s')\right]^2.∥Pπ​z∥ξ2​=s∑​ξ(s)[s′∑​p(s′∣s,π(s))z(s′)]2.
(67)

The inner term is a convex combination of the values z(s′)z(s')z(s′), which allowed us to apply Jensen’s inequality to the convex function x↦x2x \mapsto x^2x↦x2. For the optimal Bellman operator, we would need to bound:

[max⁡a∑s′p(s′∣s,a)z(s′)]2.\left[\max_{a} \sum_{s'} p(s'|s,a) z(s')\right]^2.[amax​s′∑​p(s′∣s,a)z(s′)]2.
(68)

But the maximum of convex combinations is not itself a convex combination. It is a pointwise maximum. Jensen’s inequality does not apply. We cannot conclude that max⁡a[Paz]\max_a [\mathbf{P}_a z]maxa​[Pa​z] is non-expansive in any weighted L2L^2L2 norm.

Is convergence of PL\Proj \BellmanPL with Galerkin projection impossible, or merely difficult to prove? The situation is subtle. In practice, fitted Q-iteration and approximate value iteration with neural networks often work well, suggesting that some form of stability exists. But there are also well-documented divergence examples (e.g., Q-learning with linear function approximation can diverge). The theoretical picture remains incomplete. Some results exist for restricted function classes or under strong assumptions on the MDP structure, but no general convergence guarantee like the policy evaluation result is available. The interplay between the max operator, the projection, and the norm geometry is not well understood. This is an active area of research in reinforcement learning theory.

From Abstract to Practical: Fitted-Value Iteration¶

We have developed weighted residual methods through abstract functional equations: choose test functions, impose orthogonality conditions ⟨R,pi⟩w=0\langle R, p_i \rangle_w = 0⟨R,pi​⟩w​=0, solve for coefficients. But what are we actually computing when we solve these equations by successive approximation? The answer is simpler than the formalism suggests: function iteration with a fitting step.

Recall that the weighted residual conditions ⟨v−Lv,pi⟩w=0\langle v - \Bellman v, p_i \rangle_w = 0⟨v−Lv,pi​⟩w​=0 define a fixed-point problem v=PLvv = \Proj \Bellman vv=PLv, where P\ProjP is a projection operator onto span(Φ)\text{span}(\boldsymbol{\Phi})span(Φ). We can solve this by iteration: vk+1=PLvkv_{k+1} = \Proj \Bellman v_kvk+1​=PLvk​. Under appropriate conditions (monotonicity of P\ProjP, or matching the weight to the operator for policy evaluation), this converges to a solution.

In parameter space, this iteration becomes a fitting procedure. Consider Galerkin projection with a finite state space of nnn states. Let Φ\boldsymbol{\Phi}Φ be the n×dn \times dn×d matrix of basis evaluations, W\mathbf{W}W the diagonal weight matrix, and y\mathbf{y}y the vector of Bellman operator evaluations: yi=(Lvk)(si)y_i = (\Bellman v_k)(s_i)yi​=(Lvk​)(si​). The projection is:

θk+1=(Φ⊤WΦ)−1Φ⊤Wy.\boldsymbol{\theta}_{k+1} = (\boldsymbol{\Phi}^\top \mathbf{W} \boldsymbol{\Phi})^{-1} \boldsymbol{\Phi}^\top \mathbf{W} \mathbf{y}.θk+1​=(Φ⊤WΦ)−1Φ⊤Wy.
(69)

This is weighted least-squares regression: fit Φθ\boldsymbol{\Phi} \boldsymbol{\theta}Φθ to targets y\mathbf{y}y. For collocation, we require exact interpolation Φθk+1=y\boldsymbol{\Phi} \boldsymbol{\theta}_{k+1} = \mathbf{y}Φθk+1​=y at chosen collocation points. For continuous state spaces, we approximate the Galerkin integrals using sampled states, reducing to the same finite-dimensional fitting problem. The abstraction remains consistent: function iteration in the abstract becomes generate targets, fit to targets, repeat in the implementation.

This extends beyond linear basis functions. Neural networks, decision trees, and kernel methods all implement variants of this procedure. Given data {(si,yi)}\{(s_i, y_i)\}{(si​,yi​)} where yi=(Lvk)(si)y_i = (\Bellman v_k)(s_i)yi​=(Lvk​)(si​), each method produces a function vk+1:S→Rv_{k+1}: \mathcal{S} \to \mathbb{R}vk+1​:S→R by fitting to the targets. The projection operator P\ProjP is simply one instantiation of a fitting procedure—Galerkin and collocation correspond to specific choices of approximation class and loss function.

Algorithm 5 (Fitted-Value Iteration)

Inputs: Finite state set S\mathcal{S}S (or sample {si}i=1n\{s_i\}_{i=1}^n{si​}i=1n​), discount factor γ\gammaγ, function class F\mathcal{F}F, fitting procedure fit\mathtt{fit}fit, convergence tolerance ϵ\epsilonϵ

Output: Approximate value function v^≈v∗\hat{v} \approx v^*v^≈v∗

  1. Initialize v0∈Fv_0 \in \mathcal{F}v0​∈F arbitrarily

  2. Set k←0k \leftarrow 0k←0

  3. repeat

  4. \quad for each state si∈Ss_i \in \mathcal{S}si​∈S do

  5. \quad\quad Compute target: yi←max⁡a∈A{r(si,a)+γ∑s′p(s′∣si,a)vk(s′)}y_i \leftarrow \displaystyle\max_{a \in \mathcal{A}} \Big\{ r(s_i, a) + \gamma \sum_{s'} p(s' \mid s_i, a) v_k(s') \Big\}yi​←a∈Amax​{r(si​,a)+γs′∑​p(s′∣si​,a)vk​(s′)}

  6. \quad end for

  7. \quad Fit new approximation: vk+1←fit({(si,yi)}i=1n;F)v_{k+1} \leftarrow \mathtt{fit}\big(\{(s_i, y_i)\}_{i=1}^n; \mathcal{F}\big)vk+1​←fit({(si​,yi​)}i=1n​;F)

  8. \quad k←k+1k \leftarrow k+1k←k+1

  9. until ∥vk−vk−1∥<ϵ\|v_k - v_{k-1}\| < \epsilon∥vk​−vk−1​∥<ϵ (or maximum iterations reached)

  10. return vkv_kvk​

The abstraction fit\mathtt{fit}fit encapsulates all the complexity of function approximation, whether that involves solving a linear system, running gradient descent, or training an ensemble. The projection operator P\ProjP is one instantiation: when F\mathcal{F}F is a linear subspace and we minimize weighted squared error, we recover Galerkin or collocation. Neural networks and other non-linear methods extend this framework beyond theoretical tractability.

A limitation of this algorithm is that it assumes we can evaluate the Bellman operator exactly. Computing yi=(Lvk)(si)y_i = (\Bellman v_k)(s_i)yi​=(Lvk​)(si​) requires knowing transition probabilities and summing over all next states. In practice, we often have only a simulator or observed data. The next chapter shows how to approximate these expectations from samples, connecting the fitted-value iteration framework developed here to simulation-based methods and reinforcement learning.

The Minimum Residual Framework for Nonlinear Approximators¶

The weighted residual methods developed in this chapter have focused on linear function classes: polynomial bases, piecewise linear interpolants, and linear combinations of fixed basis functions. Neural networks, kernel methods, and decision trees do not fit this template. How does the framework extend to nonlinear approximators?

Recall the Galerkin approach for linear approximation vθ=∑i=1dθiφiv_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} = \sum_{i=1}^d \theta_i \varphi_ivθ​=∑i=1d​θi​φi​. The orthogonality conditions ⟨v−Lv,φi⟩w=0\langle v - \Bellman v, \varphi_i \rangle_w = 0⟨v−Lv,φi​⟩w​=0 for all iii define a linear system with a closed-form solution. These equations arise from minimizing ∥v−Lv∥w2\|v - \Bellman v\|_w^2∥v−Lv∥w2​ over the subspace, since at the minimum, the gradient with respect to each coefficient must vanish. The connection between norm minimization and orthogonality holds generally. For any norm ∥⋅∥w\|\cdot\|_w∥⋅∥w​ induced by an inner product ⟨⋅,⋅⟩w\langle \cdot, \cdot \rangle_w⟨⋅,⋅⟩w​, minimizing ∥f(θ)∥w2\|f(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|_w^2∥f(θ)∥w2​ with respect to parameters requires ∂∂θi∥f(θ)∥w2=0\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_i} \|f(\boldsymbol{\theta})\|_w^2 = 0∂θi​∂​∥f(θ)∥w2​=0. Since ∥f∥w2=⟨f,f⟩w\|f\|_w^2 = \langle f, f \rangle_w∥f∥w2​=⟨f,f⟩w​, the chain rule gives 2⟨f,∂f∂θi⟩w=02\langle f, \frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta_i} \rangle_w = 02⟨f,∂θi​∂f​⟩w​=0. Minimizing the residual norm is thus equivalent to requiring orthogonality ⟨f,∂f∂θi⟩w=0\langle f, \frac{\partial f}{\partial \theta_i} \rangle_w = 0⟨f,∂θi​∂f​⟩w​=0 for all iii. The equivalence holds for any choice of inner product: weighted L2L^2L2 integrals for Galerkin, sums over collocation points for collocation, or sampled expectations for neural networks.

For nonlinear function classes parameterized by θ∈Rp\boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathbb{R}^pθ∈Rp (neural networks, kernel expansions), the same minimization principle applies:

θ∗=arg⁡min⁡θ∥vθ−Lvθ∥w2.\boldsymbol{\theta}^* = \arg\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} \|v_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} - \Bellman v_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}\|_w^2.θ∗=argθmin​∥vθ​−Lvθ​∥w2​.
(70)

The first-order stationarity condition yields orthogonality:

⟨vθ−Lvθ,∂vθ∂θi⟩w=0for all i.\Big\langle v_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} - \Bellman v_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}, \frac{\partial v_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}{\partial \theta_i} \Big\rangle_w = 0 \quad \text{for all } i.⟨vθ​−Lvθ​,∂θi​∂vθ​​⟩w​=0for all i.
(71)

The test functions are now the partial derivatives ∂vθ∂θi\frac{\partial v_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}{\partial \theta_i}∂θi​∂vθ​​, which span the tangent space to the manifold {vθ:θ∈Rp}\{v_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} : \boldsymbol{\theta} \in \mathbb{R}^p\}{vθ​:θ∈Rp} at the current parameters. In the linear case vθ=∑iθiφiv_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} = \sum_i \theta_i \varphi_ivθ​=∑i​θi​φi​, the partial derivative ∂vθ∂θi=φi\frac{\partial v_{\boldsymbol{\theta}}}{\partial \theta_i} = \varphi_i∂θi​∂vθ​​=φi​ recovers the fixed basis functions of Galerkin. For nonlinear parameterizations, the test functions change with θ\boldsymbol{\theta}θ, and the orthogonality conditions define a nonlinear system solved by iterative gradient descent.

The dual pairing formulation Legrand & Junca (2025) extends this framework to settings where test objects need not be regular functions. We have been informal about this distinction in our treatment of collocation, but the Dirac deltas δ(x−xi)\delta(x - x_i)δ(x−xi​) used there are not classical functions—they are distributions, defined rigorously only through their action on test functions via ⟨N(v),δ(x−xi)⟩=(Nv)(xi)\langle \Residual(v), \delta(x - x_i) \rangle = (\Residual v)(x_i)⟨N(v),δ(x−xi​)⟩=(Nv)(xi​). The simple calculus argument for orthogonality does not apply directly to such objects; the dual pairing framework provides the proper mathematical foundation. The induced dual norm ∥N(v)∥∗=sup⁡∥w∥=1∣⟨N(v),w⟩∣\|\Residual(v)\|_* = \sup_{\|w\|=1} |\langle \Residual(v), w \rangle|∥N(v)∥∗​=sup∥w∥=1​∣⟨N(v),w⟩∣ measures residuals by their worst-case effect on test functions, a perspective that has inspired adversarial formulations Zang et al. (2020) where both trial and test functions are learned.

The minimum residual framework thus connects classical projection methods to modern function approximation. The unifying principle is orthogonality of residuals to test functions. Linear methods use fixed test functions and admit closed-form solutions. Nonlinear methods use parameter-dependent test functions and require iterative optimization. Convergence guarantees are well understood for linear projections (monotonicity, matched weightings) but remain an active research area for neural networks. The next chapter extends this framework to the simulation-based setting, where the Bellman operator itself must be approximated from samples rather than computed exactly.
